Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 43213 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
Sustaining Asia's Growth and Investment in a 
Changing World 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management, trade and services, finance sector development) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability), 
regional cooperation and integration (other regional public goods) 
Location impact  –  National (high), regional (high) 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  U. Schäfer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Chief Economist  J. W. Lee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
   
Team leader  D. Brooks, Principal Economist, ERD 
Team members  L. Sumulong, Senior Economics Officer, ERD  
  A. Terada-Hagiwara, Economist, ERD  
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  ongoing  global  financial  and  economic  crisis  has  halted  the  robust  growth 
developing Asian economies enjoyed until 2007. The rapid deterioration in industrial countries’ 
economic  growth  resulting  from  the  current global  economic  and  financial crisis  has  been 
translated into weaker economic prospects for developing Asia, which remains heavily reliant on 
external  demand  as  its  engine  of  growth.  The  global  downturn  has  adversely  affected 
developing  Asia's  exports  (particularly  to  industrial  countries)  and  has  reduced  regional 
domestic demand because of reductions in incomes. In addition, the financial sectors in some 
regional economies have seen increases in capital outflows, weaker remittances, and shrinking 
dollar-denominated funding. Regional growth declined in 2008 from the nearly 2-decade peak 
achieved in 2007 and is expected to be clipped further in 2009. As a result, more than 60 million 
people will remain trapped in poverty than would have been the case if previously high growth 
rates had continued. This research and development technical assistance (TA) aims to provide 
appropriate policy prescriptions to allow Asia to return to its high long-term growth trajectory and 
continue its fight against poverty. 
2.  The severity of the current turmoil has led to assistance and research efforts by the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  International  Monetary  Fund,  the  Organisation  for 
Economic Co-operation and Development, the World Bank, and the Group of 20 (G20). They 
have undertaken programs and projects to respond swiftly to the crisis and to address the 
adverse effects of the global downturn on their member economies.  
3.  Within  ADB,  research  in  the  regional  and  knowledge  departments  is  focused  on 
identifying the impacts of the crisis on the region, and on providing the necessary assistance for 
ADB's developing member countries (DMCs) so they can cope with the global slowdown. Thus, 
the TA envisages close collaboration between the Economics and Research Department (ERD), 
the other knowledge departments, and the regional departments, particularly in terms of the 
study's focus and its implementation arrangements. The TA design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1.1 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Sustainable growth. Before the global crisis that began in 2008, Asia had experienced  
years of rapid growth. However, this growth has been mainly driven by massive demand for 
Asia's exports from outside the region and a collapse in demand for the region's exports has  
adversely affected Asia's economic growth. Nevertheless, Asia is poised to lead the global 
economic recovery, as regional governments and central banks have undertaken effective fiscal 
stimulus measures and easier monetary policies. Asia now faces the challenge of being the 
world's engine of growth and recovery. In the transition to full recovery, demand from industrial 
countries is likely to continue declining. In this situation, the short-term issue is how Asia can 
increase domestic demand to sustain its growth. In the long term, there is a need to implement 
supply-side  structural  policies  to  improve  the  productivity  of  investments  and  enhance 
technological progress. 
5.  Rebalance growth. For Asia to be the world's engine of growth and recovery, it must 
reduce its reliance on extra-regional demand. The region must strive to diversify its sources of 
growth. Strengthening domestic demand is imperative. In particular, this involves encouraging 
consumption by reducing the precautionary motive for savings among households. In the short

2   
term, raising consumption can boost growth. However, enhancing the investment climate and 
promoting  small-  and  medium-sized  enterprises  and  service  industries  will  also  bolster 
production from firms that cater to domestic demand. In the long term, it is important to focus 
more on investment because, in addition to the initial boost to growth that it provides, it also 
contributes  to  capital  accumulation,  leading  to  more  productive  activities,  and  generating 
additional growth in succeeding years. However, there are several key questions. How can Asia 
use its comparative advantage for its development? What are the industries where Asia has 
comparative advantage? What should be the role of government? Should government target 
industries or should it just improve the investment climate? 
6.  Broaden openness. Asia must broaden its openness to foreign trade and capital flows. 
Since the region has suffered from the adverse consequences of overreliance on extra demand 
for its exports from outside the region, it must expand its internal markets, particularly for final 
goods.  While  trade  within  Asia  has  been  gradually  increasing,  this  growth  has  been 
concentrated  on  parts  and  components  that  support  regional  production  networks. 
Strengthening intraregional trade in final goods will help reduce Asia's overdependence on 
industrial countries. However, how can Asia strengthen its trade in final goods rather than in 
parts and components? How can it strengthen intraregional investment that supports regional 
production networks catering to intraregional demand? Asia still needs to improve its domestic 
institutional capacity to ensure that shifts in capital flows are less destabilizing to its economies. 
This primarily involves encouraging a shift toward longer-term capital inflows such as direct 
investments by improving the investment climate.  
7.  Regional cooperation and integration. In its efforts to rebalance growth and broaden 
openness, Asia must adopt policies to enhance regional cooperation. Reducing border barriers 
to intraregional trade can speed up the process of trade integration among regional economies. 
Speeding  up  the  realization  of  the  Asian  Bond  Markets  Initiative  will  allow  the  region  to 
successfully tap and mobilize its large savings pool for investment. The Chiang Mai Initiative will 
act as an insurance mechanism, making a $120 billion regional foreign reserve pool available 
for countries in the region needing financing.2  
8.  This  TA  proposes  to  deepen  and  extend  understanding  of  the  long-term  growth 
prospects of developing Asia, taking into account the effects of the ongoing financial and 
economic crisis. In particular, it will examine, through a careful review of trends and alternative 
scenarios, and through the use of sensitivity analysis, how a move from export-oriented growth 
to domestic-demand-driven growth can effectively include more consumption and investment, 
enhanced social development and social safety nets, and stronger regional cooperation. The 
methodology for specific analyses will be finalized during the inception workshop. 
                                                 
2  In response to the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis, the finance ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations, the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea (ASEAN+3) agreed to promote the 
Chiang Mai Initiative (CMI). The goal of CMI is to address short-term liquidity problems and supplement existing 
international financial arrangements. In February 2009, the ASEAN+3 agreed to increase the fund from $80 million 
to $120 billion.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will support a study that will look at the medium- and long-term impacts of the 
global crisis on developing Asian economies through a reassessment of an export-led growth 
strategy, and comparing it with a domestic-demand-led growth strategy and a more balanced 
growth  strategy.  It  will  develop  policy  recommendations  for  the  inclusive  and  sustainable 
development of the developing Asian region. 
10.  The impact of the TA will be to generate effective policy advice that will allow developing 
Asian economies to rebalance their growth. This will be measured by an evaluation of whether 
the economic policies and development strategies adopted by ADB strike a balance between 
the contributions of domestic and external demand to economic growth. The TA will support an 
extensive  analysis  of  how  the  ongoing  global  crisis  will  change  the  global  financial  and 
economic landscape. Economic policies and development strategies to achieve inclusive and 
sustainable development will need to take this changed environment into consideration.  
11.  The  objective  of  the  TA  will  be  to  improve  countries'  understanding  of  which 
development strategies and policies are most effective in minimizing extreme business cycle 
fluctuations and achieving inclusive and sustained economic growth. Options for alternative 
development strategies and policies will be made available to policy makers and practitioners so 
they may make an informed assessment of which among the various alternative development 
strategies would be relevant for their economies. The study will provide strategies not only for 
national development, but also for regional cooperation and integration. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The study will take stock of previous and ongoing work by ADB and other multilateral 
and  research  organizations  on  the  medium-  and  long-term  impacts  of  the  ongoing  global 
financial and economic crisis on developing Asia. In undertaking this review, ERD will work 
closely  with  other  knowledge  departments  and  all  regional  departments.  The  study  will 
undertake a reassessment of the export-led growth strategy and an evaluation of the main 
alternative growth strategies (a domestic-demand-led growth strategy and a more balanced 
growth strategy) for developing Asia. This reassessment and evaluation may be carried out in 
partnership  with  the  ADB  Institute,  research  institutions  and  universities,  and  well-known 
international scholars. These scholars are expected to produce five background papers that will 
be used as inputs for the TA final report.  
13.  An inception workshop, a midterm review workshop, and a finalization conference will be 
organized. These workshops may be cosponsored with other organizations undertaking related 
research. The inception workshop will be organized in month 4 to discuss the crisis impacts and 
identify the key challenges facing the region. The midterm review workshop will be organized in 
month  7  to  discuss  evaluations  of  the  alternative  growth  strategies.  Representatives  from 
governments and regional groupings (such as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the 
South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation, as well as ADB programs on the Greater 
Mekong Subregion, South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation, and Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation) will be invited during the midterm review meeting to encourage policy 
discussion  and  dialogue  at  an  early  stage.  National  and/or  regional  consultations  with 
stakeholders (e.g., policy makers and civil society organizations) may also be held to extend the 
study's reach in ADB's DMCs.

4   
14.  Based  on  the  evaluation  of  growth  strategies,  the  study  will  identify  policy 
recommendations  that  will  contribute  to  the  inclusive  and  sustainable  development  of 
developing Asian economies. The recommendations will not be limited to national policies, but 
will include policies for regional cooperation and integration. The finalization conference will be 
held in month 10 to disseminate the study's findings and to advocate for the adoption of policies 
to support inclusive and sustainable growth. 
15.  The TA final report will be drafted in months 11-12 and published as a book by month 
16. The draft outline of the final report is in Appendix 2. The book's executive summary will be 
published separately. The book will be disseminated in months 17-18 through a variety of 
outreach activities. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $800,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB's funding program (Technical Assistance Special Fund-IV). Details of 
the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, which will be managed by ERD. The TA is 
expected to be carried out over 18 months, from December 2009 to May 2011. All outputs will 
be subject to interdepartmental review and to external review during the workshops or the 
finalization conference. 
18.  The TA will require 16 person-months of international consulting services, 24 person-
months of national consulting services, and 1.4 person-months of resource persons' services. 
The  consultants  to  be  engaged  include  macroeconomists,  an  economics  editor,  a  copy 
editor/typesetter, a project manager, and a secretary. The consultants will be engaged by ADB 
in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). All consultants will be selected on an individual basis. Coordination and administrative 
support will be carried out by ERD. The terms of reference for consultants and resource persons 
are  in  Appendix  4.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook3. 
19.  The TA report will be drafted by the project team and the international consultants. The 
lead consultant will be responsible for drafting the overview. The other chapters will be prepared 
by the rest of the consultants. The economics editor and copy editor/typesetter will ensure that 
the publication is of high quality and adheres to ADB style. A project manager and secretary will 
be hired to facilitate implementation of the TA. Resource persons will be engaged to serve as 
discussants during the workshops and to provide comments on the background papers. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Sustaining Asia's Growth and Investment in a Changing World, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

Appendix 4  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The research and development technical assistance (TA) will be administered by the 
Economics  and  Research  Department  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  in  close 
coordination with the other knowledge departments and all regional departments. A team of six 
individual international consultants, who are macroeconomists, will form the TA core group that 
will carry out most of the TA activities. They will be engaged for a total of 13 person-months, 
and will prepare background papers for the study. In addition, two individual national consultants 
will be engaged for a total of 24 person-months to facilitate the study's daily management and 
operations. One national consultant will be the project manager and the other one the project 
secretary. Ten international resource persons, who are experts in macroeconomics, will be 
engaged for 1.4 person-months to serve as discussants during the workshops. An economics 
editor and copy editor/typesetter, engaged for 1.5 person-months each, will ensure that the TA 
output is presented as a high quality ADB publication. 
 
A.  International Consultants and Resource Persons  
 
1.  Lead Consultant: Macroeconomist (3 person-months) 
 
2.  Under the supervision of the project team leader in ERD, the international expert will be 
responsible for conceptualizing, designing, and undertaking research to identify development 
challenges for selected economies in Asia that have been adversely affected by the ongoing 
global economic and financial crisis. The expert will participate in workshops and consultations 
to present the findings of his research study. 
 
3.  The  international  expert  should  have:  (i)  a  PhD  degree  in  economics;  (ii)  expert 
knowledge of development issues in developing Asia; (iii) proven capacity for both quantitative 
and policy-oriented analysis; and (iv) proven capacity to synthesize complex issues and identify 
key policy messages for policymakers, donors, and other stakeholders. The candidate should 
have proven track record serving as a project advisor or team leader in similar assignments 
before. 
 
  2.  Consultants: Macroeconomists (10 person-months)  
 
4.  Under the supervision of the project team leader in ERD, five international experts will be 
responsible for conceptualizing, designing, and undertaking research to identify development 
challenges for selected economies in Asia that have been adversely affected by the ongoing 
global  economic  and  financial  crisis.  The  topics  will  cover  sustainable  growth,  growth 
rebalancing, broadening openness, and regional cooperation and integration. The experts will 
participate in workshops and consultations to present the findings of their respective research 
studies. 
 
5.  The international experts should each have: (i) a PhD degree in economics; (ii) expert 
knowledge of development issues in developing Asia; (iii) proven capacity for both quantitative 
and policy-oriented analysis; and (iv) proven capacity to synthesize complex issues and identify 
key policy messages for policy makers, donors, and other stakeholders. 
 
3.  Resource Persons: Macroeconomists (1.4 person-months)  
 
6.  Under the supervision of the team leader in ERD, 10 resource persons will be engaged 
to participate as discussants in the midterm review workshop and finalization conference. The

resource  persons  should  have  (i)  expert  knowledge  of  development  issues  in  Asia,  and  
(ii) extensive experience in applied economic research and development policy. 
 
  4.  Consultant: Economics Editor (1.5 person-months) 
 
7.  Under the supervision of the project team leader in ERD, the economics editor will be 
engaged to ensure the high quality of the publication. The consultant will: (i) review and revise 
the draft reports to ensure the chapters constitute a consistent report, (ii) assist in integrating the 
overall findings and in reflecting these in the overview chapter of the book, and (iii) ensure that 
the edited materials adhere to ADB style and conform to high publication standards. 
 
8.  The consultant should have: (i) a PhD degree in economics; (ii) expert knowledge of 
development issues in developing Asia; and (iii) proven capacity to synthesize complex issues 
and identify key policy messages for policymakers, donors, and other stakeholders. 
 
  5.  Consultant: Copy Editor/Typesetter (1.5 person months) 
 
9.  Under the supervision of the project team leader in ERD, a copy editor/typesetter will be 
engaged  to  ensure  that  materials for  the  book  adhere  to  ADB  style  and  conform  to  high 
publication standards. The copy editor/typesetter will lay out the text, tables, charts, and convert 
the files into the required format for publication. 
 
10.  The consultant should possess expertise in copy editing and desktop publishing, and 
preferably have extensive experience in similar assignments involving preparation of economic 
publications. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Project Manager (12 person-months)  
 
11.  Under the supervision of the project team leader in ERD, the national expert will be 
responsible for the management of the day-to-day activities of the project, under the supervision 
of ADB staff. 
 
12.  The  national  expert  should  have:  (i)  a  master's  degree  in  economics;  (ii)  expert 
knowledge of development issues in developing Asia; and (iii) proven capacity to coordinate 
project events such as workshops, conferences, and consultations. 
 
2.  Secretary (12 person-months)  
 
13.  Under the supervision of the project team leader in ERD, the national expert will be 
responsible for supporting the project manager in the management of the day-to-day activities of 
the project. 
 
14.  The national expert should have: (i) a university degree; (ii) expert knowledge of filing, 
database management, and other administrative skills; and (iii) proven capacity to coordinate 
project events such as workshops, conferences, and consultations.
